ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Critical thinking, and a different approach to classical texts on modern political theory
such an amazing, condensed overview of the main traditions of political theory: where the field has been, is now, and is going
I learned a lot about political theory, specifically different ways in which the state can be legitimized. Different thought processes have been used throughout history, it was pretty cool.

I learned about the fundamental ideas that underlay political theory, and help contextualize the relationship between the individual and the state. Some of the material was the predictable entry-level kind of stuff you would find anywhere, but some of it was more unconventional and expanded my thinking, and some of it was simply odd and unnecessary.
I thought my ability to take big chunks of readings and find the key points and arguments of each work increased as the semester progressed.
I read important authors and interacted with interesting ideas about political theory.
Really cool and interesting political theories and this history of political thought
A wide variety of 20 or so philosophers and their main ideas, as well as five (or six) methods of evaluating whether a state is legitimate.
Learned about the political theory behind various philosophers, became well-versed in a variety of political ideologies, and wrote interesting essays.
Learned about some well-known political philosophers. Class was centered around the legitimacy of the state.
I learned about early modern and contemporary political philosophers.
I learned about Social Contract Theory, Marxism, Anarchy, Democracy, Communitarianism, and Utilitarianism as applied to political philosophy.
Knowledge of political theory lol

Introduction to a range of political philosophers from early modern contract theorists (Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau) up through present-day thinkers. Many different conceptions of how to justify the state.

I learned how to question political theory in a way I hadnt before. I learned there is no single way to define a successful government. I learned that each form of government legitimacy we learned can be understood through a variety of lenses. I learned how to put various political theories into conversation.
I learned a lot about many contemporary and older political thinkers and their theories. We also learned about the critiques of many of these theories.

I got to see where some major political movements originated in often a relatively concise form (as in, I was often only asked to read a chapter or two of a book, sometimes more, but never anything so much as the entire book). I learned where conservatism came from, some the major discussions in political theory, and some of the ideas of authors I had meant to getting around to read (including Locke, Rousseau, Rawls, Nozick, Marx, and Burke; to.be sure, these were not the only authors read during the course).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The way it is structured is very good. In fact, it has a great component of non-ideal theory, which is not common in this sort of course.

strengths: the contents of the course connected really well, truly inspirational authors with great mix, very fair amount of reading
improvements:  Nietzsche! (sometimes talked about authors without really knowing their work)
I really liked the format of lecture, I think section could have been a little more talkative for everyone, but a lot of the readings were difficult enough to where people did not know what to say

Strengths - low workload, if that's your thing. Some of the readings are genuinely very interesting and will challenge your ideas of politics and society. 
Weaknesses - the professor is all over the place, the course follows no coherent path, and it isn't really clear how we end up learning the things that we do. 
This course needs a clear narrative and a syllabus that builds each unit on the previous one, not an eclectic collection of books and theories from various time periods and standings.
The regular section complements the lectures very well.
The lectures were not great, and often felt unnecessary after having done the readings.
No weaknesses and the strengths are too many to list. It cannot be improved

S - Great variety of philosophers
W - Lectures are a bit short

Strengths: interesting discussions and essay prompts, amazing feedback on essays, great support from TA's and professors. 
Weaknesses: n/a

Class was organized very well. Professor Steinmetz was a great lecturer, and the TFs were really nice and helpful. I got detailed feedback and help with my papers (I did the Writing Intensive). no major complaints!
Professor Steinmetz was very engaged and passionate about the topic. The weakness is that some of the material is boring, but it isn't the professor's fault.
A lot of reading that doesnt get done

While I loved the material, I think the readings were often a little two dense. I wish we read shorter sections more in depth. I feel like I could have gotten more out of the readings that way. Other than that, the class was strong.
I like the lecture style this course was taught in, and the fact that we were able to debate interesting moral and philosophical questions during class.

I would love sections to have been longer. The presentations were a nice touch, but once you add presentations, it is usually only after 25 or 30 minutes that we actually start to discuss the material. In a 50-minute section, that might mean only 20 minutes of discussion, where one might be expecting 50 minutes, which was often a big disappointment.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course. It is an opportunity to engage with major works in political theory. Alicia is very friendly and makes great explanations, inviting students to take different perspectives on the readings and not simply to memorize them.
absolutely: super low-stakes introduction to most important political questions
Yes, I think it is a great introduction to the ideas behind general political theory.

I would not recommend this class so long as it is taught by Dr. Steinmetz. If you have the opportunity, do yourself a favor and take Moral Foundations of Politics, which deals with lots of the same ideas with a much better lecturer.

Yes. Very interesting course and I liked noticing that my knowledge of the topics increased as we got to more contemporary works, and I could more clearly see how each broad subject was connected to each other.
I would recommend it if the student needs it as an EPE prerequisite, otherwise probably not  the poor lectures were not worth it for the good reading.
Absolutely

Yes! I surprisingly loved this course. The organization of the class was clear, straight forward, and comprehensive. The philosophers cover a wide range of topics and ideologies, and you will leave knowing a lot about the ideas of the last several hundred years.
Yes, it is a great way to get a writing credit. If you are interested in political philosophy but don't have much of a background in it, this is the course to take.
Yes!! Gets you started with thinking about moral legitimacy of governments and gives an excellent skillset for thinking about liberalism, conservatism, libertarianism--all very applicable.
Yes, if you want to learn about political philosophy in the last century!
Yes, if you like reading about political philosophy. No if youre illiterate like me.
I would. It teaches you the basics of political theory, which is good to have under your belt.

It's a decent introduction to political philosophy. Definitely interesting concepts and not much work (if you're in the non-writing section, the only assignments were the midterm and final, and the reading was manageable). I wasn't very engaged with this class and felt that not many people were doing the readings, paying attention in lecture, etc which made the class less rewarding. I think it could be a solid course if you put more into it than I did.
Yes. It was very interesting and a great intro to polysci.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are intersted in political theory and different modes of organizing society.

I really wanted to take Moral Foundations of Politics for this EP&E requirement, but this was the course available that satisfied this requirement this semester. I would still be tempted to take MoFoPo over this course, as nothing from the course seemed to be particular special.
